p: Micellization, as an isolation technique helps in the preservation of native state of protein and removal of non–protein components [ 60]. Protein precipitate by ‘salting out’ at different salt concentrations. The most commonly used salt is ammonium sulfate, due to its high solubility, minimal cost and lack of buffering capacity relative to other salts [ 66]. Micellization involves protein extraction with salt solution, usually in an ice bucket, followed by removal of insoluble material by centrifugation, recovery of precipitates by centrifugation, diafiltration to remove excess salts and final recovery by centrifugation [ 60, 66]. Proteins extracted by micellization have low phytic acid and pentosans levels, higher enthalpies (meaning high structural order), and are lightly coloured [ 60]. However, ammonium sulphate precipitation can be onerous [ 66]. Micellization has been used to isolate flaxseed proteins to 93% yield [ 67].
